Merck Frosst Canada & Co. (applicant) and The Minister of Health Canada (respondent)
Indexed  <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED> )
Counsel:
Karine Joizil, for the applicant;
Marie Crowley, for the respondent.
Solicitors of Record:
Fasken, Martineau, DuMoulin LLP, Montréal, Québec, for the applicant;
Morris Rosenberg, Deputy Attorney General of Canada, Ottawa, Ontario, for the respondent.
Summary:
This case is unedited, therefore contains no summary.

[1]
Pinard, J.
: This is an appeal from the decision of Prothonotary Tabib sustaining the respondent's objections to the applicant's questions during the cross-examination on affidavit of the respondent's witnesses Margery Carole Snider and Serge Durand. The questions at issue concern the process followed by the respondent in reaching his decision dated December 19, 2001, to partially disclose certain records under section 28 of the Access to Information Act (the "ATIA"). The respondent's decision is the subject-matter of the within application for review pursuant to section 44 of the ATIA.

[2]
The respondent objected to the questions on the ground that they are irrelevant. Prothonotary Tabib agreed with the respondent's position and stated the following in her decision:
All the other objections relate to the decisional process followed by the respondent and the material considered by the affiants in arriving at their decisions or recommendations. Whether the principles to be applied by this Court on an application pursuant to section 44 of the Access to Information Act is a determination de novo, as propounded by the respondent or a review based on the standard of correctness as suggested by the applicant, the issue of how and on the basis of what information the respondent arrived at its decision is not relevant to the determination of this application. As to the validity of the questions as a means of testing the witnesses' credibility, I find that the credibility of the affiants is not put in issue in these proceedings in such a way as to render relevant the questions objected to.

[3]
Upon hearing counsel for the parties and upon reading the material filed, I am not prepared to conduct a de novo review of the merits of the impugned decision and to exercise my own discretion differently because the applicant has failed to demonstrate that the Prothonotary's decision is "clearly wrong", in that it was based upon an incorrect principle of law or a misapprehension of the facts, or that the question raised is vital to the "final issue" in the case (see  <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED>  [2003] S.C.J. No. 23 (S.C.C.) (QL)). Indeed, I am of the opinion that the Prothonotary applied the correct legal principle of relevance in deciding that the respondent's objections should be sustained. In the underlying application for review pursuant to section 44 of the ATIA, the Court is not reviewing the legality of the respondent's decision, but will decide de novo, based in part on new evidence that was not before the respondent, whether the information contained in the records is of such a confidential or prejudicial nature that it should be exempt from disclosure under section 20 of the ATIA. Considering that the credibility of the affiants is not at issue, the questions related to the respondent's decision-making process are wholly irrelevant to the issues to be determined by the Court.

[4]
Consequently, the motion is dismissed, with costs.
[End of document]

legal_issues: The appropriate standard of review applicable to decisions made under access to information legislation.
The relevance of evidence concerning a decision-making process when the core issue is the confidentiality or prejudicial nature of the information itself.
Whether inquiry into the credibility of witnesses is permissible or necessary when reviewing a decision under access to information legislation.
The scope of permissible inquiry during examination of evidence in proceedings related to access to information requests.
factual_background: Merck Frosst Canada & Co. appealed a decision made by a Prothonotary.
The appeal concerned objections raised by The Minister of Health Canada to questions during cross-examination of witnesses Margery Carole Snider and Serge Durand.

The questions pertained to the process followed by The Minister of Health Canada in reaching a decision on December 19, 2001, regarding partial disclosure of records under section 28 of the Access to Information Act (ATIA).
The Minister of Health Canada objected to the questions as being irrelevant.
The Prothonotary sustained the objections, finding the questions irrelevant to the application for review under section 44 of the ATIA.
The underlying application for review concerns a decision by The Minister of Health Canada regarding the disclosure of records, potentially involving exemptions under section 20 of the ATIA.
The court will consider new evidence not previously before The Minister of Health Canada in determining whether the information should be exempt from disclosure.

Applicants: The Prothonotary’s decision was “clearly wrong” because it was based on an incorrect principle of law or a misapprehension of the facts.
The questions regarding the respondent’s decision-making process were vital to the “final issue” in the case.
The review should be based on a standard of correctness, not de novo.
Questions relating to the respondent’s decision-making process were relevant to testing the witnesses’ credibility.
Respondents: The Court should conduct a de novo review of the merits of the impugned decision.
The credibility of the affiants was not put in issue in a way that would render the questions relevant.
The Court is not reviewing the legality of the respondent’s decision, but deciding de novo whether information should be exempt from disclosure under section 20 of the ATIA.

court_analysis: The court affirmed the Prothonotary’s decision to sustain the respondent’s objections to questions regarding the decision-making process behind the partial disclosure of records under the Access to Information Act (ATIA).

The court clarified that a review under section 44 of the ATIA does *not* involve reviewing the legality of the respondent’s original decision; instead, the court conducts a *de novo* review focused on whether the information *should* be exempt from disclosure under section 20 of the ATIA, considering new evidence not previously before the respondent.
Because the review is *de novo* and considers new evidence, the court found the process by which the respondent initially reached its decision to be irrelevant to the current inquiry.

The court specifically stated that the credibility of the affiants was not at issue in the proceedings, further supporting the finding that questions about the decision-making process lacked relevance.

The court agreed with the Prothonotary’s application of the legal principle of relevance and found no error in the initial decision, stating the applicant failed to demonstrate the Prothonotary’s decision was “clearly wrong” based on incorrect law, misapprehension of facts, or a vital issue to the final determination.
final_outcome: Costs are awarded to the respondent
